comment._content: From Wikipedia regarding Ballysaggartmore Towers which was owned by the Anson family at one time, "Keily-Ussher died c.1862 and the estate was sold by a liquidator. The house, gardens and some of the lands were purchased by the Woodroofe family and these were later owned by a family named Anson." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ballysaggartmore_Towers Ballysaggartmore Towers, www.flickr.com/photos/mpobrien/4589354919/

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content:
From an interview with an old time cowboy:
"I used to work for the 7's, which was later changed to the (f h triangle). This ranch was owned by Claude [Anson?] and Hubert Verner. They were Englishmen and, I think, belonged to the nobility. Their headquarters were on Kickapoo Creek. Anson always rode for his best mount, a gray cuttin' horse. A story is told of two negroes who worked on the ranch. At one time when Anson and Verner were away on a trip, possibly to England, these two negroes, one tall like Anson and one low in stature like Verner, would put on the Englishmen's clothes, ride their top horses and go to town; passing themselves off as ['Mr.?] Anson and ['Mr.?] Verner. That wasn't impossible. People in those days didn't inquire anything about you as long as you attended to your own business."

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] Fantastic story! Kickapoo Creek couldn't have been further removed from Lismore, Waterford (geographically and metaphorically).
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: More on life on the ranch: They got engaged and were married the following February 1901 and after a honeymoon in America went to the ranch. This was about the size of Co. Waterford as in that climate with constant danger of droughts much more land was needed per beast than here. The nearest town was 23 miles away and there was no road. They had to drive in a buggy straight across the prairie. Their nearest neighbour was the post master who had a very long neck. He had been lynched for horse stealing and only just cut down in time by his friends. Although there were so few people the gossip was terrific. Everything that happened was known in the town and round about. Two elderly men who had a 60 year old housekeeper were told this was improper and one of them must marry her. They drew lots and the loser did it. Mother and an Irish maid who went out with her thought they would try to fill up holes in the ground near the ranch house with stones and the gossips said this was most unladylike. From Ansons at Ardmore by Clodagh Anson (daughter of the Hon Claude and Lady Codagh) on the Waterford County Museum website.

comment.author: 38020241@N07
comment._content:
Fotograficamente hablando,diria que es una fotografia de excelente factura-refleja la personalidad de este caballero...Por otro lado,rescato la nobleza rasgos que habla en si misma la imagen de discreta elegancia ... como siempre, memorias de un pasado no tan lejano.
Anemarie

comment.author: 63163769@N00
comment._content: This image is so perfect already, I almost didn't want to do any post editing on it, but I just wanted to be with it awhile, so I cropped it some and put him in a more atmospheric surrounding. This aristocratic/cowboy is a very interesting fellow and I love the stories that this image has generated. To me, he seems to represent the archetypical post -Victorian nobleman and gentleman.
